The five-year accident history [40 CFR 68.155(d)]:
The Suez WTS New Philadelphia plant has had no accidental release that resulted in an employee injury within the past 5 years.
The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]:
Our Chemical release response program contains these elements:
1.	Identification of emergency organization personnel structure and functional responsibilities
2.	Quarterly inspections to check safety control devices and detect hazards
3.	Fire Extinguisher Training
4.	Fire drills conducted at the facility
5.	Spill and release control instructions
6.	Evacuation procedures and external response notifications
7.	Incident coordination with local emergency responders
8.	Incident analysis and review with plant personnel, and identification of procedure changes
9.	Annual program review and any necessary re-training
Planned changes to improve safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]:
Suez is committed to improving our safety systems. Regular review of our program ensures a successful and safe facility.

Suez has completed this report to provide the public with information about our activities at this facility.  We believe that the many controls instituted to maintain a safe operation, and our commitment to continuous improvement that an incident affecting our employees or the surrounding area is unlikely to occur.

The Suez WTS New Philadelphia plant covers 14.7 acres of property, of which 3.1 acres is used for offices, warehouse(s), production facilities and outdoor material storage. The balance is used for access roads, parking lot and open lawn or idle areas. The regulated substance at the facility is Cyclohexylamine, and it is a raw material stored onsite as a liquid in a bulk storage tank. The material is used to produce water treatment chemicals and is stored in a protected area and isolated from combustion sources.
The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps [40 CFR 68.155(c)]:
The purpose of the program is to define steps that are taken to identify, evaluate and prevent or mitigate releases of hazardous chemicals that could occur as a result of failures in processes, procedures or equipment. The prevention program includes elements that include:

Safety Information [40 CFR Part 68.48]
Compilation of process safety information related to the process.

Hazard Review [40 CFR Part 68.50]
Performance of process hazard review to identify and evaluate potential release scenarios. Complete any recommendations resulting from a hazard review in a timely manner.

Written Operating Procedures [40 CFR Part 68.52]
Development and use of operating procedures and safety procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations and normal shutdown. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Our company senior management and the facility personnel are committed to safety and implementation of safe procedures. We operate under our parent company, Suez WTS USA Inc, policy for Safety, Health & environment. This policy states:

Suez is committed to achieving environmental, health and safety excellence. This is the responsibility for management and employees in all functions. Suez will strive to provide a safe and healthy working environment and to avoid adverse impact and injury to the environment and the communities in which we do business. Our programs must combine clear leadership by management, the participation of all employees and functions, and the use of appropriate technology in developing and distributing Suez products and services.

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]:
Comply with applicable environmental, health and safety laws and regulations.

Take appropriate measures to prevent workplace injuries and illnesses, and to provide employees with a safe and healthy working environment. Consider evolving industry practices, regulatory requirements and societal standards of care.

Assess EHS impacts before starting a new activity or project. Consider EHS impacts in the design and production of Suez products and services.

Eliminate unreasonable risks from Suez facilities, products, services and activities.
To the extent reasonably practicable, reduce the use and release of toxic and hazardous materials, prevent pollution and conserve, recover and recycle materials.

Continue to improve our EHS systems and performance as an integral part of Suez operational strategy.
